Required background knowledge.text: There is required background knowledge to understand the first clause.

Try to predict what you think the Mishna.text: The first clause of the Mishnah is speaking about whether a man is allowed to create a binding engagement with a woman via a messenger. Do you think this should be possible? Why or why not?

Read the first clause.text: In order to read the first clause of the Mishnah “האיש מקדש בו ובשלוחו”:

Identify where the sentence ends.text: How do we know where the first clause of the Mishnah ends? Even if we don't know the meaning of the words, we should be able to notice some similar-looking patterns being repeated:

tokens.text: את בתו כשהיא נערה בו ובשלוחו

Identify where the sentence ends.text: Based on this pattern, we should be able to recognize that the Mishnah is composed of three similar parts, and we can begin by focusing on the first one:

tokens.text: האשה מתקדשת בה ובשלוחה האיש מקדש את בתו כשהיא נערה בו ובשלוחו

General translation of האיש.text: In general the word “האיש” means “the man.”

Contextual translation of האיש.text: In this context, it means “a man” because we’re not speaking about any one man in particular. Sometimes the Mishnah will use the word “the” slightly differently than we would in English.

Grammatical explanation of האיש.text: We can giev a grammatical explanation of האיש:

tokensOfLine.targetTopic: Hebrew definite article
tokensOfLine.enclosingTopic: First pass of האיש מקדש בו ובשלוחו

How you could figure the meaning of האיש.text: Here’s how you could figure out the meaning of האיש yourself:

tokensOfLine.text: First, let's remember that we're reading a Mishnah and so the language is going to be Hebrew and not Aramaic.
Next, we should see if any of the letters are potentially prefixes or suffixes rather than being part of the underlying word.
ה is sometimes a prefix, but ש is never a suffix, so we can conclude that either “האיש” is one big word, or the ה is a prefix, and the real word is איש.

(It could also be that ה is a prefix and א is another prefix after that, but א is only a prefix in the Hebrew future tense first person (e.g. “I will run”), and there’s no situation in Hebrew where you can have a ה prefix followed by a future tense verb.)
Thus, we can look up the word “האיש” in the dictionary, see that it doesn’t exist, and then try “איש,” and we would see that it does exist and is a noun meaning “man.”
Once we know איש is a noun, the ה prefix can't be any of the

tokensOfLine.targetTopic: Verb forms beginning with ה
tokensOfLine.enclosingTopic: First pass of האיש מקדש בו ובשלוחו
tokensOfLine.enclosingSubtopic: How you could figure the meaning of האיש out yourself

General translation of מקדש.text: To translate the word מקדש in general, first we should note that it is an ongoing “ing” verb like “running,” and it refers to someone who is making holiness in some way. For example:

tokensOfLine.text: , which means Hashem makes the Sabbath holy by designating it as special.
before a holiday meal, this is referred to as “being
When a man wants to marry a woman, he must first create the “binding engagement” stage called
, and doing so is refered to as the man “being

General translation of מקדש.text: The word מקדש is also in the “masculine singular,” so we are speaking about one man doing the action. So, מקדש means some man or masculine entity is doing one of the previously mentioned actions in an ongoing way.

Contextual translation of מקדש.text: We can give a contextual translation of the word מקדש.

tokensOfLine.text: In this context, we are in

so we know we are probably speaking about marriage, and so even though “מקדש” can have several meanings, here we are probably referring to a man who is creating the binding engagement stage of marriage called

However, the ongoing nature of the verb makes it sound like we are telling a story about a particular man doing this, but that seems a bit out of place here, and so we’ll have to remember that in the Mishnah, the ongoing “present tense” is used to communicate halachic rulings, and so if it says “we are making
” that might mean “individuals are obligated to make kiddush” and if it says “a man is buying an item with a contract,” that would mean “a man is
to buy an item using a contract.”
Thus, the word מקדש here means “[a man is] able to create the
stage of marriage [...],” and we are anticipating further details about how this is done.

Grammatical explanation of מקדש.text: We can give a grammatical explanation of the word מקדש:

tokensOfLine.text: מקדש is in the masculine singular, so we are speaking about one man or one masculine entity.

How you could figure the meaning of מקדש.text: Here's how you could figure out the meaning of מקדש yourself:

tokensOfLine.text: First, let's remember that we're reading a Mishnah, and so the language is going to be Hebrew.
We might know that there is a noun spelled מקדש, מִקְדָּשׁ meaning temple or sanctuary, but because we just saw האיש which is a noun, now we are probably looking for a verb.
So, every verb should have 2-3 visible letters of the

How can we understand the specificity of.text: When the Mishnah gives a list of things, is that generally davka, lav davka, or the biggest chiddush and kol shekain all less-surprising examples?

Whose opinion are we trying to figure ou.text: Is there someone whose mind we could read to see if R Yosef is correct about what he is saying? (Getting the student to recognize that this is a machlochus over the intent of the tana, not stam over what the halacha is.)
